did.langmaterial: The material is in English and Arabic
did.abstract: Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri was the director of the Islamic Center of America and the writer of many renowned works on Islam. The collection consists primarily of correspondence, newspaper clippings, photographs, memorandums, board minutes, writing drafts, publications and newsletters related to Chirri and the Islamic Center of America.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in December 2008 by Adnan Jawad Chirri (donor no. 10144). Additions were received in November 2009.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri was born in Lebanon on October 1, 1905. He was a graduate of the theological Institute of An-Najaf Al-Ashraf University in Iraq. In 1948, the small Muslim community in the Detroit area invited Imam Chirri to the United States of America. As the spiritual leader to the primarily Lebanese-American community, Imam Chirri envisioned the construction of a new mosque which would help strengthen the local Muslim population as well as enlightened non-Muslims throughout America on the practices of Islam.

In 1959, a little over a decade after arriving in America, Imam Chirri traveled to Egypt seeking financial assistance for the construction of the mosque he envisioned for the growing Detroit area Muslim community. While in Egypt, Imam Chirri met with President Jamal Abdul Nasser who provided the Islamic Center with a donation large enough to purchase land on Joy Road and Greenfield. During his visit to Egypt, Imam Chirri also met with Sheikh Mahmood Shaltut, Imam of the Al-Azhar University of Cairo. The two spiritual leaders participated in lengthy discussions about the similarities between Shi-ite Jaafari and Sunnite. After their discussions, Imam Shaltut made the historic announcement declaring the equality between the Shi-ite Jaafari and Sunnite Schools.

Three years after his trip to Egypt, the Islamic Center of Detroit (which would later be renamed the Islamic Center of America) opened its doors in 1962. The new center and mosque allowed for weekly Sunday services and became the social center of the strengthening community.

Along with being the founder of the Islamic Center of America, Imam Chirri was a renowned author and lecturer. Imam Chirri published widely in Arabic, but the self-taught English speaker also wrote many celebrated works in English. Some of his writings include Inquiries About Islam, The Faith of Islam, and Imam Hussein, Leader of the Martyrs. His writings and position as the director of the Islamic Center of America made Imam Chirri a widely sought after authority on Islam. His views and insights on topics related to Islam and the Muslim community were often quoted in the national media.

Over a decade after Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri's death in 1994, the Islamic Center of America opened a new center on Ford Road in 2005. The new center is the home of one of largest mosques in North America.

scopecontent.p: The Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri Papers document the cleric's religious, leadership, and scholarly activities as well as the inner workings of the Islamic Center during Chirri's tenure and after his death. The collection consists primarily of correspondence, newspaper clippings, photographs, memorandums, board minutes, writing drafts, publications and newsletters. The material is generally in English, unless otherwise noted. The collection contains the following series: Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri, Islamic Center of America, Zehia Kahil and Publications.

scopecontent.p: Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri series reflects Chirri's significant role in shaping and managing the Islamic Center of America and his scholarly contributions to the study of Islam. The series consists primarily of correspondence, newspaper clippings, photographs, writing drafts, and publications. The series contains two subseries: Personal/Background, and Writings, Drafts and Notes.

The Personal/Background subseries includes newspaper clippings, correspondence, and photographs reflecting Chirri's standing as an authority on Islam and a guiding figure at the Islamic Center of America.

did.unittitle: Commemorations on the death of Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri 1994-2003
Portraits and Photographs of Chirri at ICA and other events, undated

scopecontent.p: The Writings, Drafts and Notes subseries documents the development of Chirri's celebrated writings. The material is generally undated, unless otherwise noted. The drafts have been organized by title and usually contain multiple edited versions of the particular writing rather than the published version. The titles are listed alphabetically under English Titles, Arabic Titles, or Notebooks. English Titles indicates that the drafts are written in English, whereas Arabic Titles indicates that the drafts are written in Arabic. The series also contains thirty-eight of Chirri's notebooks. The notebooks are primarily in Arabic and contain drafts and notes for sermons and book chapters. When more than one title is listed this indicates that the notebook is a combined volume and contains multiple drafts or book chapters.

scopecontent.p: Islamic Center of America series documents over 40 years of the Islamic Center of America's administrative services and community activities. The series includes correspondence, flyers, photographs, religious material, and reports. The series contains three subseries: Administrative, Activities, and Subject Files.

The Administrative subseries contains background material related to the overall functioning of the Center including board minutes, contribution and donor lists, financial statements, reports, community surveys, laws and guidelines. The contribution and donor lists have been included in the collection because they provide an indication of active persons involved with the Center; however, it is important to note that the contributors may have asked that their donations not be recorded believing that God does not want humans showing their charity. The sub-series also documents the planning, construction, and completion of the Grand Mosque and new Islamic Center of America building on Joy Road.

did.unittitle: "A statement presented to the Chairman, present and previous members of the Board of Trustees of the Islamic Center of America, May Allah bless them all; from Mohamad Baker Chirri, servant of the Muslims and brother of the founding Imam," undated
Grand Mosque, Ground Breaking Ceremony Photographs undated
Specifications for ICA on Joy Road undated

scopecontent.p: The Activities subseries contains newspaper clippings, religious material, event announcements, and memorandums and petitions on political and social issues affecting the Muslim community abroad. The subseries reflects the Islamic Center of America's involvement within the Detroit/Dearborn community.

did.unittitle: Newspaper clippings on ICA and Islam in Detroit/Dearborn Area 1972-1998

scopecontent.p: The Subject Files subseries contains files from the Islamic Center of America, which contains correspondence and other documents from the Center's multiple religious leaders as well as a file containing correspondence documenting the Center's search for a librarian. The sub-series contains a file with material originating from Imam Chirri causing some overlap with the Imam Mohamad Jawad Chirri series.

Zehia Kahil series documents the activities of the first Muslim woman to be elected the head of an Islamic organization. The series contains correspondence, notes, meeting agendas and minutes, and newspaper clippings from organizations in which Kahil held an administrative position. The organizations represented in the series include the Arab World Festival, Federation of Islamic Associations, and the Order of the Eastern Star.

Publications series contains newsletters and publications created or collected by the Islamic Center of America. Many of the publications are newsletters from outside Islamic associations primarily from North America but also from abroad. Some of the newsletters are more complete than others. For example, the series contains a very comprehensive collection of the Muslim Star but contains only two issues of the Palestine Digest. The series also contains booklets and scholarly publications on Islam.
